author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 10 of the N.F.L. Season
description: DeAndre Hopkins pulled down a catch that will live forever, Ronald Jones II ran Tampa Bay to victory and Ben Roethlisberger was no worse for the wear after a week of no practice.
content: A Hail Mary into triple-coverage. A 98-yard touchdown run. A roughing the passer call that handed a team a win. It was a week of big plays and last-minute changes in fortune, and it shook up the N.F.L.’s best division, as the N.F.C. West now has a three-way tie for first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Biden’s China Policy? A Balancing Act for a Toxic Relationship
description: As president, Joe Biden will face deep dilemmas, and a lot of unfinished business, stemming from President Trump’s multiyear onslaught against China.
content: WASHINGTON — In addition to a deadly pandemic and a weakened economy, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will inherit one more challenge when he takes office in January: a toxic relationship with the world’s second-largest economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Hate Crimes in U.S. Rose to Highest Level in More Than a Decade in 2019
description: An F.B.I. report on hate crimes also found that more murders motivated by hate were recorded in 2019 than in any year before.
content: Hate crimes in the United States rose to their highest level in more than a decade last year, while more murders motivated by hate were recorded than ever before, the F.B.I. said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A second coronavirus vaccine has posted promising results.
content: A second pharmaceutical company is reporting encouraging results on a coronavirus vaccine that has far exceeded expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: With Marlins Job, Kim Ng Is ‘Bearing a Torch for So Many’
description: Major League Baseball’s first female general manager said she had received an outpouring of support since her hiring was announced on Friday.
content: Since the Miami Marlins named Kim Ng as their new general manager on Friday, making her the first woman to hold that title in any of the major men’s sports leagues in North America, she said she had been flooded with well over a thousand emails and text messages of congratulations. The senders included current and former managers, scouts, front office executives, players, family and friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon and Natalie Prieb
title: I❤️NY in Crisis: How Do Tourist Shops Survive With No Tourists?
description: After the coronavirus lockdown wiped out tourism in the city, souvenir stores remain empty.
content: Like many souvenir stores in New York City, Memories of New York in Manhattan is packed with shirts. They bear the logos of the Yankees and select subway lines, images of the Brooklyn Bridge and, of course, the familiar “I ❤️NY” insignia that is a staple of city souvenir shops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon, Lucy Tompkins, Audra D. S. Burch and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: With 11 Million Cases in the U.S., the Coronavirus Has Gotten Personal for Most People
description: What was once a health crisis that Americans feared has evolved into one virtually everyone has experienced up close. That will affect behavior, but in many different ways.
content: Just a few weeks ago, Kem Kemp, a high school teacher in Houston, knew no one personally who had tested positive for the coronavirus. Then her roommate came down with a deep cough and was diagnosed with Covid-19. Her brother, a dentist in Amarillo, Texas, also tested positive. A neighbor fell sick with the virus. Two faculty members at the private school where she teaches were required to quarantine. And in the last few days, so were two of the  students she advises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Jacques Pépin and the Art of Making the Most of It
description: “Jacques Pépin Quick & Simple,” an updated cookbook, offers useful lessons in economy for trying times.
content: [The Best Books of 2020: View our full list.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: The President vs. the American Media
description: After terrorist attacks, France’s leader accuses the English-language media of “legitimizing this violence.”
content: The president has some bones to pick with the American media: about our “bias,” our obsession with racism, our views on terrorism, our reluctance to express solidarity, even for a moment, with his embattled republic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Weber
title: Lindy McDaniel, Ace Reliever for Mediocre Teams, Dies at 84
description: Over 21 seasons — including eight with the Cardinals and six with the Yankees — he was one of the game’s most dependable closers but never made the postseason.
content: Lindy McDaniel, who pitched for 21 years in the big leagues and became one of baseball’s most dependable relievers in spite of the mostly mediocre teams he labored for, died on Saturday in Carrollton, Texas. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Peru Chooses 3rd President in a Week Amid Street Protests
description: The naming of Francisco Sagasti as president was not expected to immediately quell popular anger at the country’s legislators, whom many Peruvians see as corrupt — and responsible for the turmoil.
content: Peru’s legislature on Monday selected the country’s third president in a week, seeking to stanch growing street protests over lawmakers’ decision to remove a popular president from office last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: A Pattern of Leniency Toward Officers Accused of Misconduct
description: A New York Times analysis found that the Police Department routinely reduced or ignored a review board's recommendations for disciplining officers.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Should Schools or Employers Be Allowed to Tell People How They Should Wear Their Hair?
description: Do employers or school administrators have the right to make rules about hairstyles, hair color and facial hair?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: How are you adapting Thanksgiving this year?
description: We’d like to know how your traditions will change.
content: As coronavirus cases surge ahead of Thanksgiving, many families and friend groups are swapping out big holiday gatherings for pandemic-friendly celebrations. Some people are planning to drop off food at relatives’ houses. Others are sharing and cooking recipes so that they can enjoy the same meal together on Zoom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerry Hannon
title: For Small-Business Owners, a Shifting Landscape of Resources
description: With the end of the Paycheck Protection Program loan program, entrepreneurs are forced to look elsewhere.
content: Small businesses across the United States have been pounded by the pandemic. Entrepreneurs have been forced to make drastic cuts and pivot to new business models to keep going. Financial aid, though, is what has kept the lights on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba and Joseph Plambeck
title: What You Need to Know About the Election and Disinformation
description: Monday: Our colleagues in the technology bureau help us understand the proliferation of misinformation about the election playing out.
content: Today’s newsletter is a dispatch from our colleagues in the tech bureau who have been covering the spread of disinformation in the aftermath of the election. First this from Davey Alba:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Heat Waves May Be Bad for Your Pregnancy
description: Each one-degree Celsius increase in temperature was associated with a 5 percent increase in preterm birth and a 5 percent increase in stillbirth.
content: Heat waves may lead to poor pregnancy outcomes, a review of studies has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Powell
title: Liberals Envisioned a Multiracial Coalition. Voters of Color Had Other Ideas.
description: Democrats may need to rethink their strategy as the class complexities and competing desires of Latino and Asian-American demographic groups become clear.
content: The proposition seemed tailor-made for one of the nation’s most diverse and liberal states. California officials asked voters to overturn a 24-year-old ban on affirmative action in education, employment and contracting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Ad giant WPP is folding its Geometry agency into VMLY&R.
description: WPP, one of the largest advertising companies in the world, is further condensing its sprawling operations by folding its Geometry agency into its VMLY&R agency.
content: WPP, one of the largest advertising companies in the world, is further condensing its sprawling operations by folding its Geometry agency into its VMLY&R agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Finally, New Jersey Might Be Cooler Than New York
description: If we’re judging by willingness to legalize recreational marijuana, that is.
content: HOBOKEN, N.J. — In the very important, high-stakes fight for tristate area coolness, New Jersey rarely has the upper hand. (The tristate, for those without a Northeast-centric worldview, has traditionally referred to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Japan’s Economy Surges, but the Comeback May Not Last
description: Activity has jumped as pandemic limits have eased, in a positive sign for global growth, but damage may be deeper than the initial numbers showed.
content: TOKYO — Japan became the latest major economy to bounce back from the devastation of the coronavirus, as lockdowns eased and pent-up demand led to surging domestic consumption and a rebound in exports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ethan Hauser, Mike Baker, Lucy Tompkins and Tracey Tully
title: In the absence of a White House response, states move to slow infections.
description: In Chicago, a sweeping stay-at-home advisory goes into effect on Monday. Philadelphia is expected to announce new restrictions on movement later in the day. In-person classes for high school and college students in Michigan have been canceled.
content: In Chicago, a sweeping stay-at-home advisory goes into effect on Monday. Philadelphia is expected to announce new restrictions on movement later in the day. In-person classes for high school and college students in Michigan have been canceled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: A Lesson for Humanity From 17 Million Doomed Creatures
description: If this pandemic has taught us anything it’s that we cannot escape the world we have shaped.
content: It was the photo of the mink in Denmark, soon to be slaughtered, that hit me the hardest. In it, the animals peer from their cages with open curiosity, ears pricked forward, clever fingers grasping the wire of the cage doors as they study their surroundings. They are clearly trying to figure out what is happening.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hurricane Iota Makes Landfall in Nicaragua
description: Forecasters warn that the storm could compound the destruction caused by Hurricane Eta, which pounded Central America less than two weeks ago. Iota made landfall about 15 miles from where Eta touched down.
content: This live coverage has ended. See our most recent updates on Hurricane Iota here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: How Pediatricians Are Fending Off Coronavirus Myths
description: Doctors report misinformation at both extremes, with some parents worrying about taking impossible precautions and others encouraged to believe their children can’t get infected.
content: As a trained physician, I pride myself on thinking sensibly about risks, reading reputable scientific studies, evaluating their quality, and making sound, evidence-based decisions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Division Among the Democrats
description: After the party lost seats in the House of Representatives on Election Day, some are pointing fingers and debating which wing was at fault.
content: For four years, Democrats had been united behind the mission of defeating President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dalmeet Singh Chawla
title: Surviving Weed-Out Classes in Science May Be a State of Mind
description: Social ties to classmates and how students feel could be more important than innate ability when it comes to enduring early STEM courses.
content: “Look to your left, look to your right. One of you won’t be here in the next semester.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Slone
title: What Could Be More Comforting Than a Quilt Coat?
description: Old patchwork blankets are getting new life as garments. But some preservationists cringe at ripping up heirlooms for fickle fashion.
content: After Cassandra Siegenthaler’s mother died in June 2019, Ms. Siegenthaler, going through her things, found a tattered, threadbare wedding ring quilt from the 1930s tucked inside an antique cedar chest. “My mother’s family was estranged so I don’t really know a lot about the origins of the quilt, but I do know it was one of the only things from her mom that she had saved,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: A former right-wing media creator on how a ‘different reality’ became so prominent.
description: Matthew Sheffield grew disillusioned after years of working in conservative media.
content: Matthew Sheffield started his first conservative website in 2000, dedicating it to criticizing the former CBS News anchor Dan Rather, who Mr. Sheffield believed was a partisan liberal and not critical enough of President Clinton during the Monica Lewinsky scandal. Mr. Sheffield then went on to help create NewsBusters, another right-leaning website that criticized the mainstream media for liberal bias. Later, he became the founding online managing editor of the Washington Examiner, another popular outlet for conservative views.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Felder
title: Can a YouTube Queen Like Bethany Mota Create a Jewelry Realm?
description: At 25, she’s already done “Dancing With the Stars” and written a memoir. Next up: tiny white sapphires.
content: Bethany Mota, the video blogger whose chatty posts about makeup and clothing have attracted nearly 10 million subscribers to her namesake YouTube channel, is adding another profession to an already long résumé: designer of demi-fine jewelry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Benjamin Novak
title: Hungary and Poland Threaten E.U. Stimulus Over Rule of Law Links
description: The two illiberal governments, having been enabled by the bloc’s leaders and evaded punishment, now hold a 1.8 trillion euro package hostage.
content: BRUSSELS — When European Union leaders announced a landmark stimulus package to rescue their economies from the ravages of the coronavirus, they agreed to jointly raise hundreds of billions of dollars to use as aid — a bold and widely welcomed leap in collaboration never attempted in the bloc’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: The Man Who Wouldn’t Concede
description: When it comes to Trump, there is no bottom.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, you sometimes write columns asking readers to vote for the worst members of the Trump administration. With that in mind, what are your candidates for the worst moments in the Trump presidency? His behavior since Joe Biden became president-elect has got to be in the Top 5. What else?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Pro-E.U. Candidate Wins Moldova Election Over Putin-Backed Rival
description: Maia Sandu, who has called for closer ties with the European Union, will become the country’s first female leader.
content: MOSCOW — Maia Sandu, a Harvard-educated economist who supports closer ties with the European Union, has won a presidential election in Moldova against an incumbent whom President Vladimir V. Putin had openly endorsed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexa Weibel
title: 19 Make-Ahead Recipes for Thanksgiving Day
description: A little planning goes a long way to help a holiday meal come together easily.
content: When planning a holiday menu, it’s important to take into account time and real estate as much as taste. What will fit in the oven or stovetop on the big day, and what can you make in advance? Whether cooking for one, two or a few, get ahead with a little planning and strategy, and your day-of tasks will be minimal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
title: Democrats and Republicans face perhaps the most up-for-grabs electoral landscape in a generation.
description: WASHINGTON — America’s two major parties had hoped the 2020 presidential election would render a decisive judgment on the country’s political trajectory. But after a race that broke records for voter turnout and campaign spending, neither Democrats nor Republicans have achieved the upper hand.
content: WASHINGTON — America’s two major parties had hoped the 2020 presidential election would render a decisive judgment on the country’s political trajectory. But after a race that broke records for voter turnout and campaign spending, neither Democrats nor Republicans have achieved the upper hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: Tourism, Engine for N.Y.C. Economy, May Not Fully Recover Until 2025
description: A new forecast projects a rebound in visitors starting in mid-2021 and taking at least four years to return to pre-pandemic totals.
content: Double-decker sightseeing buses carried fewer than 10 passengers on runs around Manhattan on Monday. Big ferries arrived at the Statue of Liberty with their lower decks nearly empty. Some of the city’s largest hotels had few guests, while others were housing homeless men who had been cleared out of shelters to curb the spread of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Is it safe to go to a holiday get-together?
description: The vaccines will not reduce the risk of infections over the holiday season.
content: The vaccines will not reduce the risk of infections over the holiday season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Fargo’ Season 4, Episode 9 Recap: And a Little Dog, Too
description: This week’s episode was an audacious shaggy dog story full of twists and turns and stylistic flourishes. We’re not in Kansas (City) anymore.
content: One of the challenges of serialized television shows, especially plot-heavy thrillers like “Fargo,” is that the demands of moving the various subplots forward can keep individual episodes from having their own distinct flavor. The fourth season has fallen into that mid-season trap a little, sacrificing the thematic purposefulness of the early episodes for a little too much plate-spinning. It needed an audacious, standalone hour like this week’s episode to reassert itself again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Big Sky’ and ‘Between the World and Me’
description: Ryan Phillippe stars in a new drama from the creator of “Big Little Lies”; a screen adaptation of a Ta-Nehisi Coates work comes to HBO; and “Supernatural” ends its 15-season run.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Nov. 16-22. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Different Virus Responses
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: As the coronavirus has surged again in recent weeks, much of the United States has chosen to keep restaurants open and schools closed. Much of Europe has done the opposite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs, Melina Delkic and Chris Cameron
title: More Republicans call for a smooth transition as Trump continues spreading baseless fraud claims.
description: Even as more top Republicans urged President Trump on Sunday to allow for an orderly presidential transition, the president himself, after briefly appearing to acknowledge his election loss, resumed spreading the kinds of baseless accusations of election fraud that his supporters have embraced.
content: Even as more top Republicans urged President Trump on Sunday to allow for an orderly presidential transition, the president himself, after briefly appearing to acknowledge his election loss, resumed spreading the kinds of baseless accusations of election fraud that his supporters have embraced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josiah Edwards
title: Living Near Drilling Is Deadly. Why Don’t California Lawmakers Care?
description: The state may be phasing out gas-powered cars, but it’s still legal to put an oil well right next to an elementary school.
content: California famously prides itself on environmental leadership — but what about when its lawmakers overlook problems in their own constituents’ backyards? It’s still legal to drill for oil there right next to schools and hospitals — despite well documented health risks to anyone nearby. In the video op-ed above, Josiah Edwards explains what it was like to grow up breathing in the toxic chemicals expelled by drilling. He traces the asthma that plagues his entire family to decades of redlining in Los Angeles County, which consigned Black and brown communities like theirs to live next to active oil wells. Even today, politicians keep rejecting legislation that would help protect Californians from these poisonous emissions. You may not have an oil drill in your backyard now, but if you live in California, there’s nothing stopping one from moving in tomorrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alden Wicker and Elizabeth Paton
title: For a Leading Light of Indian Fashion, All That Glitters Is Not Gold
description: Manish Arora was the breakout fashion star of India. Today, his business is in tatters, with a trail of debts. What happened?
content: In September, Manish Arora, a fashion designer once described as the “John Galliano of India,” announced that he was creating a pop-up restaurant in Paris, his adopted hometown, for the Holi festival. An Instagram slide show, featuring the brightly colored maximalism that is the Indian designer’s signature, depicted Mr. Arora with assorted friends sampling traditional Indian snacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: grandstand
description: This word has appeared in 30 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Parties Hunting for a Message After a Split-Decision Election
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 16, 2020.
content: “The more outrageous one sounds, the greater exposure they get to the public. But it just deepens the divisions and worsens the climate in the country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Trump, the Absolute Worst Loser
description: He has spent his life gaming the system, so it’s no surprise that he can’t accept defeat.
content: Donald Trump lost the election. He knows it. But he won’t admit it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Teens in Covid Isolation: “I Felt Like I Was Suffocating’’’
description: In this lesson, students learn why a loss of social ties is especially severe for teenagers, then consider how to cope both now and when the pandemic is over.
content: Featured Article: “Teens in Covid Isolation: ‘I Felt Like I Was Suffocating’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: How Does Ina Do It?
description: Ina Garten, a.k.a. the Barefoot Contessa, has a loyal, diverse and growing fan base that follows her anywhere — even through quarantine and a Thanksgiving lockdown.
content: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — Ina Garten’s house, on a side street in the stately, manicured village of East Hampton, was just the way you’d want it to be on a sunny morning in October. By which I mean the lawn was a beautiful rumpled green, and the garden was full of cherry tomatoes, and she was wearing a loose button-down shirt and smiling as she brought me coffee in a hotel-style silver carafe. All appeared just as it does on her television show, “Barefoot Contessa,” that has been shot here since 2002.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Leszkiewicz
title: How to Survive a Royal Weekend on ‘The Crown’
description: In the new season, Diana Spencer’s aristocratic breeding triumphs and Margaret Thatcher’s middle-class tendencies horrify the royals. Here’s a guide to the rigid world of the British class system.
content: This article contains spoilers for Season 4 of “The Crown.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Diplomat Is Praised in China After Saving Drowning Woman
description: Relations between Britain and China are tense, but Stephen Ellison, the British consul general in Chongqing, was hailed as a hero for rescuing a woman who had fallen into a river.
content: Teetering on the edge of a slippery rock, a young woman loses her footing and plunges into a river. Moments later, she flails and then floats face-down as one shocked onlooker screams, “Hurry, hurry, save her!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: U.S. Election, Boris Johnson, Nagorno-Karabakh: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: David Andahl, 55, Dies; Elected Posthumously in North Dakota
description: He caught Covid-19 as the virus surged across the state. How to fill his vacant seat in the State Legislature remained in dispute.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gurbir S. Grewal and Jeremy Feigenbaum
title: How Progressive States Can Respond to Conservative Courts
description: We need to prepare now to protect the values and institutions that matter most.
content: President Trump and his allies in the Senate have packed the federal courts with more than 200 conservative judges over the last four years, including three Supreme Court justices. In doing so, Mr. Trump made explicit that he wants “his” judges, and the 6-to-3 conservative majority on the court, to achieve what he could not through Congress, including eliminating health care for millions and undermining what remains of the Voting Rights Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Perlroth
title: Election Security Experts Contradict Trump’s Voting Claims
description: In a public letter, 59 top specialists called the president’s fraud assertions “unsubstantiated” and “technically incoherent.”
content: Fifty-nine of the country’s top computer scientists and election security experts rebuked President Trump’s baseless claims of voter fraud and hacking on Monday, writing that such assertions are “unsubstantiated or are technically incoherent.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Denise Grady
title: How do Moderna’s early results compare with Pfizer’s?
description: [Read more on Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine.]
content: [Read more on Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.8 Million Homes in California
description: A Tudor-style cottage in Palo Alto, a contemporary home in Beverly Hills and a Spanish-style estate in North Tustin.
content: This house was designed by Pedro Joseph de Lemos, a founder of the Allied Arts Guild and the director of the museum and art galleries at Stanford University. Mr. de Lemos was an artist and architect who built a number of houses in the neighborhood, including his own residence, which was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1971. The Elizabeth F. Gamble Garden, a public park that includes a historic home and gardens, is less than half a mile away; Stanford is a five-minute drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: N.C.A.A. to Host Men’s Basketball Tournament in One City for 2021
description: The event, which is typically spread across the United States, could be held in its entirety in Indianapolis, organizers said.
content: The N.C.A.A. will consolidate its usually sprawling men’s college basketball tournament to a single city in 2021 instead of holding the games at 13 sites across the United States, in hopes of limiting travel during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Raphael Minder
title: PNC Strikes $11.6 Billion Deal to Buy U.S. Operations of Spanish Bank BBVA
description: The sale would create America’s fifth-largest retail bank.
content: PNC Financial Services said on Monday that it would acquire the U.S. business of the Spanish lender BBVA for $11.6 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Nagourney, Anna Schaverien and Adam Rasgon
title: Britain’s prime minister is quarantining, and other news around the world.
description: Seven months after he battled a serious case of Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain announced on Sunday that he was quarantining after coming into contact with a lawmaker later found to be infected.
content: Seven months after he battled a serious case of Covid-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain announced on Sunday that he was quarantining after coming into contact with a lawmaker later found to be infected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
title: Speaking on the economy, Biden says ‘we can deliver immediate relief’ and calls on Congress to act quickly.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. warned that a “very dark winter” was ahead and called on Congress to pass an economic stimulus package immediately to help workers struggling to cope with the coronavirus pandemic.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. warned that a “very dark winter” was ahead and called on Congress to pass an economic stimulus package immediately to help workers struggling to cope with the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Alexander Vedernikov, Conductor and Bolshoi Veteran, Dies at 56
description: A kinetic podium presence, he led performances at major opera houses and orchestras. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: King Von’s Debut Album Reaches the Top 5 After His Death
description: The rapper was shot and killed in Atlanta in early November. “Welcome to O’Block,” his first full studio release, climbed eight spots on the Billboard chart.
content: Late last month, the 26-year-old Chicago rapper King Von released his debut studio album, “Welcome to O’Block,” and it landed at No. 13 on the Billboard 200 chart — a modest but impressive showing for a young performer still making his way up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Academy Museum Gives Debbie Reynolds Her Due as a Costume Conservator
description: When the “Singin’ in the Rain” actress was alive, the film academy turned up its nose at her fabled costume collection. Now it has gone to her son with hat in hand.
content: LOS ANGELES — For decades, Debbie Reynolds begged Hollywood to help her preserve and exhibit her vast collection of golden age costumes. “These pieces are cultural touchstones that still carry the energy of the stars who performed in them,” she once said, referring to legends like Elizabeth Taylor and Judy Garland. “There is magic in every thread, button and bow.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The New World Order That President Biden Will Inherit
description: The importance of vision, expertise, honesty and simple decency in the management of world affairs cannot be overstated.
content: President-elect Joe Biden has signaled that he will move swiftly to restore dignity to the badly sullied image of the United States; respect for the professionals of America’s diplomatic, intelligence and military services; and a more predictable, nuanced and sympathetic approach to foreign relations. That message of a restoration of norms is likely to resonate in many capitals around the world, as it did with an electorate that gave Mr. Biden a decisive victory over Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Is Moderna in Operation Warp Speed?
description: [Read more on Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine.]
content: [Read more on Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: ‘You Could Compare It to a Picasso’: Pigeon Sells for $1.9 Million
description: New Kim, a Belgian racing bird, set an auction record after a bidding war between two Chinese buyers.
content: In the pigeon racing world, breeding brings big bucks — but never before as much as for New Kim, a 2-year-old female pigeon who sold for a record 1.6 million euros, about $1.9 million, after a bidding war between two Chinese buyers at a Belgian auction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: How Will Biden Approach School Reopenings?
description: Answer: Schools over restaurants, for now.
content: Several months into the 2020-2021 school year, things are bad and getting worse. Most American children are not in classrooms, with many suffering ill effects. The country seems doomed to face increasing coronavirus cases, hospitalizations and deaths. There seems to be little chance of improved conditions for the rest of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Charlie Savage and Helene Cooper
title: Trump Is Said to Be Preparing to Withdraw Troops From Afghanistan, Iraq and Somalia
description: Facing the end of his time in power, the president is pushing to accelerate withdrawals from counterterrorism conflicts. He campaigned on ending the longstanding wars.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump is expected to order the U.S. military to withdraw thousands of troops from Afghanistan, Iraq and Somalia by the time he leaves office in January, using the end of his time in power to significantly pull back American forces from far-flung conflicts around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas St. Fleur
title: Leonids Meteor Shower 2020: Watch It Peak in Night Skies
description: Meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.
content: All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump, Trying to Cling to Power, Fans Unrest and Conspiracy Theories
description: The president’s refusal to concede has entered a more dangerous phase as he blocks his successor’s transition, withholding intelligence briefings, pandemic information and access to the government.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s refusal to concede the election has entered a more dangerous phase as he stokes resistance and unrest among his supporters and spreads falsehoods aimed at undermining the integrity of the American voting system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Taste of Paris in Midtown
description: Angelina Paris, a staple on the Rue de Rivoli, has brought its confections and tea to New York City.
content: These days, a visit to the Rue de Rivoli across from the Tuileries Gardens in Paris is but a dream, a wish. In the meantime, Angelina — a famous Paris tearoom known for hot chocolate, and an attraction at No. 226 for more than 100 years — has come to New York, with the company’s first American branch. (There are already locations throughout Europe, Asia and the Middle East.) At the entrance to the pale, lightly gilded space, there’s a broad counter for coffee, chocolate and pastries, including the store’s Mont Blanc chestnut confection. Noémie Tessier, a pastry chef from Paris, is now in New York, where she has created a creamy Paris-New York pecan pastry. Sandwiches and packaged goods are sold for take away, and many Angelina products like chocolates, cookies and teas are also available. Some day, the dining room, where breakfast, lunch, tea and dinner will be served at marble tables, will seat 60. For now, it’s about 15. Throughout, the rooms are decorated with Cezanne-esque murals of the South of France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kerri Greenidge
title: Enslaved, Terrorized, Disenfranchised: Black Americans Still Found Ways to Change America
description: Two new works of history, “South to Freedom,” by Alice L. Baumgartner, and “The Kidnapping Club,” by Jonathan Daniel Wells, show how the actions of Black Americans have long influenced national politics.
content: SOUTH TO FREEDOM Runaway Slaves to Mexico and the Road to the Civil WarBy Alice L. Baumgartner
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Fox News’s ‘partisan right’ audience on YouTube is dropping, researchers say.
description: Fringe outlets that most aggressively pushed false information about voter fraud have seen their share of those viewers grow after the election.
content: Disinformation about election fraud is thriving on YouTube, and right-wing outlets that most aggressively push false information are gaining new, conservative viewers on the video service, according to new research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australia’s stock exchange shuts down for a day after a software glitch
description: The Australian Stock Exchange closed early on Monday following a glitch after upgrades went live, in the bourse’s worst outage since 2016.
content: The Australian Stock Exchange closed early on Monday following a glitch after upgrades went live, in the bourse’s worst outage since 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Maggie Haberman, David E. Sanger, Helene Cooper and Lara Jakes
title: Trump Sought Options for Attacking Iran to Stop Its Growing Nuclear Program
description: The president was dissuaded from moving ahead with a strike by advisers who warned that it could escalate into a broader conflict in his last weeks in office.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump asked senior advisers in an Oval Office meeting on Thursday whether he had options to take action against Iran’s main nuclear site in the coming weeks. The meeting occurred a day after international inspectors reported a significant increase in the country’s stockpile of nuclear material, four current and former U.S. officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Rachel Bloom’s Life Is an Open Book
description: The star and co-creator of “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend” wryly explores adolescent angst, adult trauma and musical theater in a new memoir, “I Want to Be Where the Normal People Are.”
content: There’s no question you can ask Rachel Bloom that runs the risk of scrutinizing her too closely. “I love that,” she said. “Please, overanalyze.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A ‘Perfect’ Pitcher, a Home Run Stealer and Two-Thirds of a Big 3
description: Mark Buehrle, Torii Hunter, Tim Hudson and Barry Zito headline this year’s list of first-time finalists for the Baseball Hall of Fame.
content: The Baseball Hall of Fame announced its new ballot on Monday, with 11 first-time candidates to go along with 14 holdovers, including four who got more than half of the votes from writers last winter: Barry Bonds, Roger Clemens, Curt Schilling and Omar Vizquel. At 70 percent, Schilling was the closest to reaching the 75 percent needed for election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
title: Joe Biden speaks about the economy as the virus surges and vaccine hopes rise.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed the slowing American economic recovery on Monday, amid the crosswinds of rising coronavirus deaths and soaring optimism over a vaccine.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed the slowing American economic recovery on Monday, amid the crosswinds of rising coronavirus deaths and soaring optimism over a vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Case on Churches, Cuomo and Coronavirus Arrives at Supreme Court
description: The general question in cases in California, Nevada and New York is whether government officials or judges should calibrate responses to the public health crisis.
content: WASHINGTON — In recent months, churches in California and Nevada asked the Supreme Court to lift government restrictions on attendance at religious services meant to address the coronavirus pandemic. The churches lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Claims of voter fraud are common. It’s the fraud that’s rare.
description: President Trump is far from the first losing politician to cast doubt on the system, but no modern president has done it more.
content: In the 1941 Orson Welles epic “Citizen Kane,” newspapermen huddle near the printing press on election night as it becomes clear that the results won’t be good news for their boss, the publishing mogul Charles Foster Kane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Chris Nikic, You Are an Ironman. And Your Journey Is Remarkable.
description: Nikic, 21, became the first person with Down syndrome to conquer the grueling endurance race, offering lessons in perseverance and hope.
content: The Florida sky had grown dark, and Chris Nikic felt ready to quit. He had been pushing through the grueling race for more than 13 hours, even though he could not navigate the course or keep the time without help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: Former Harvard Fencing Coach Accused of Taking $1.5 Million in Bribes
description: Prosecutors said a wealthy Maryland businessman, who was also charged, bribed the coach to help get his sons admitted to Harvard.
content: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — When Jie Zhao, a wealthy Maryland businessman, wanted to get his two sons into Harvard, federal prosecutors said on Monday, he made connections with the school’s longtime fencing coach, Peter Brand, who was having financial trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Cookbook From the Heart of Manhattan’s Chinatown
description: “The Nom Wah Cookbook” tells the story of a century-old restaurant on Doyers Street.
content: Nom Wah, the dim sum parlor tucked into the elbow of Doyers Street in the heart of Chinatown since the 1920s, has had its ups and downs. Recently, with Wilson Tang in charge, the trajectory has been up. And Mr. Tang has now written a cookbook that gives a thoughtful history of the place he co-owns, as well as a survey of the evolution of Chinatown and snapshots of places like Po Wing Hong grocery and Aqua Best Seafood. The recipes will not plunder your Sichuan larder as they hew closely to the traditions of Guandong Province from which earlier Chinatown immigrants came. But you will have to stock up on dumpling wrappers to attempt many of the restaurant’s dim sum items. Other, larger-format recipes — like glossy braised shiitake mushrooms, succulent Cantonese-style beef fillet and Mr. Tang’s take on Bolognese sauce over noodles, giving the dish a bit of dan-dan style — were also winners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger
title: The Cities Central to Fraud Conspiracy Theories Didn’t Cost Trump the Election
description: Yet Philadelphia, Milwaukee and Detroit have become the targets of G.O.P. allegations of voting shenanigans.
content: In Pennsylvania, much of President Trump’s attention since the election has focused on Philadelphia, where he has baselessly insisted there is a “mountain of corruption.” In Michigan, litigation by Mr. Trump’s campaign has concentrated on Detroit, where Republican poll watchers say they felt intimidated by election workers in Black Lives Matter apparel. And in Wisconsin, legal challenges and rumors have circled around Milwaukee, where one internet conspiracy  theory turns on a briefly misplaced flash drive of election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Masatoshi Koshiba, 94, Dies; Nobel Winner Tracked Ghostly Neutrinos
description: A physics teacher had flunked him, denigrating his abilities. Dr. Koshiba set out to prove the teacher was wrong.
content: Masatoshi Koshiba, who won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2002 for studies of the ghostly cosmic particles known as neutrinos, died on Thursday  in Edogawa Hospital in Tokyo. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Nov. 16, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 16, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Nov. 16, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño, Manuela Andreoni and Letícia Casado
title: As Brazil’s Covid Crisis Eases, Bolsonaro Sees Rising Popularity
description: President Jair Bolsonaro’s cavalier handling of the coronavirus pandemic drew outrage. But as the curve in Brazil has flattened, his political standing has strengthened.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Jair Bolsonaro seemed to be on a political suicide mission during the early weeks of the coronavirus crisis in Brazil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: How Accurate Was ‘The Good Lord Bird’?
description: Here’s everything you need to know about John Brown’s actual raid at Harpers Ferry, dramatized in Sunday’s series finale of the Showtime historical drama.
content: “The Good Lord Bird,” the Showtime mini-series about the incendiary career of the 19th-century abolitionist John Brown (its seven-episode run ended Sunday night), offered a stylish, consciously cockeyed view of America on the brink of the Civil War — more Lin-Manuel Miranda than Ron Chernow. But its fantastical-seeming story, based on the National Book Award-winning novel of the same name by James McBride, is more factual than casual students of American history might assume.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: More good news on the vaccine front.
content: The drugmaker Moderna announced on Monday that its coronavirus vaccine was 94.5 percent effective, based on an early look at the results from its large, continuing study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Trump’s S.E.C. Chairman Is Stepping Down
description: Jay Clayton, who has led the securities regulator since 2017, will leave by the end of the year.
content: 🚨 The DealBook Online Summit starts on Tuesday, Nov. 17. Register now to watch for free from anywhere. The newsmakers in the lineup for the first day of the two-day summit are sure to make headlines:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: Vaccine, Biden, Arctic Oil: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Joe Biden’s first economic test: the size and urgency of stimulus efforts.
description: The incoming administration’s first economic test is coming months before Inauguration Day. President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. must decide whether to push Democratic leaders to cut a quick deal on a package much smaller than they say is needed or to hold out hope for a larger one after he takes office, Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley reported in The New York Times.
content: The incoming administration’s first economic test is coming months before Inauguration Day. President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. must decide whether to push Democratic leaders to cut a quick deal on a package much smaller than they say is needed or to hold out hope for a larger one after he takes office, Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley reported in The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: One Plate to Serve You and Feed the Homeless
description: Sales of these limited-edition dinner plates provide meals for the hungry in New York City.
content: If your Thanksgiving this year is an intimate dinner for two, why not pile the turkey and stuffing on a couple of striking plates? Or buy just one for the pie or to give this holiday season? Each 10 ½-inch porcelain plate sold benefits the Coalition for the Homeless, which can provide a meal for 75 people. There are 50 designs in editions of 175 plates, each by artists like Cecily Brown, Yoshitomo Nara, Adam Pendleton, Carmen Herrera, Julie Curtiss and Wade Guyton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Greatest Gift to Loved Ones This Covid Winter? Don’t Infect Others
description: “Our biggest worry is Covid-19 fatigue,” a coronavirus expert says. “People are losing respect for the virus and letting their guard down, which is a bad idea.”
content: In case you haven’t noticed, the days are getting shorter and, in most parts of the United States, also cooler. Winter will soon descend upon the northern hemisphere along with several vacation-prone and family-centered holidays that may tempt many people to celebrate in ways they have wisely resisted for most of the Covid-19 pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Trump Admits Defea … Never Mind
description: The president briefly acknowledges Biden won before changing course: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Marchers assembled in the nation’s capital to show their support for the president, but top Republicans are increasingly urging him to accept the election’s result. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: The 2020 Hurricane Season in Rewind
description: There have been 30 named storms this year, and 13 of them were hurricanes. It’s the most active Atlantic season on record.
content: The 2020 hurricane season, which brought destructive storms from Central America to the Gulf Coast of the United States and beyond, has proved to be one for the record books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Stewart
title: Trump or No Trump, Religious Authoritarianism Is Here to Stay
description: Their unlikely ally may have lost the White House, but Christian nationalists still plan to win the war.
content: Will President-elect Joe Biden’s victory force America’s Christian nationalists to rethink the unholy alliance that powered Donald Trump’s four-year tour as one of the nation’s most dangerous presidents? Don’t count on it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At-Home Covid Tests and Other Powers of a Tech Billionaire
description: Chamath Palihapitiya made his fortune with bold predictions and bets on the future. That wealth gives him influence well beyond Silicon Valley — but should it?
content: Chamath Palihapitiya is one of Silicon Valley’s most successful tech investors. He’s also among the most candid. “I aspire to be a Koch brother before I aspire to be an under secretary,” he tells Kara Swisher on this episode of “Sway.” His definition of power has little to do with politics — it’s profits, he says, that empower you to “control the resources.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Albert R. Jonsen, 89, Dies; Brought Medical Ethics to the Bedside
description: A former Jesuit priest and leader in bioethics, he believed that an ethicist should be part of a patient’s medical team when hard decisions have to be made.
content: Albert R. Jonsen, who brought the field of bioethics to the bedside and whose way of reasoning influenced generations of medical ethicists, died on Oct. 21 at his home in San Francisco. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: When Political Theater Ditches the Disguises of Fiction
description: Four new shows are part of a movement to engage more directly in the debates of our times — sometimes even stealing the script.
content: “How is it politicians and artists have switched jobs?”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden’s adviser picks point to stronger financial regulations.
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. last week placed proponents of stronger regulation on financial regulatory teams, stoking fears by industry groups that he is preparing for an unexpected wave of corporate oversight.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. last week placed proponents of stronger regulation on financial regulatory teams, stoking fears by industry groups that he is preparing for an unexpected wave of corporate oversight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: How a Minneapolis Suburb Turned Blue, Despite Trump’s Law-and-Order Pitch
description: President Trump comfortably carried Chaska, Minn., in 2016. This time, he lost by nine percentage points — a dramatic shift that similarly played out in suburban counties across the country.
content: CHASKA, Minn. — As some protests over police brutality and systemic racism descended into vandalism and looting in Minneapolis over the summer, President Trump insisted that he was the candidate to restore “law and order” to the city. In the nearby suburb of Chaska, Minn., Mike Magusin bristled. In his view, he said, the president had fueled the unrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang and Allyson Waller
title: SpaceX’s ‘Resilience’ Lifts 4 Astronauts Into New Era of Spaceflight
description: The crew will spend some 27 hours in a capsule built by the private company before docking with the space station Monday night.
content: It’s not yet the same as hopping on commuter flight from New York to Washington or renting a car from Avis, but Sunday’s launch of four astronauts to the International Space Station in a capsule built by SpaceX was a momentous step toward making space travel commonplace and mundane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Gabler and Abby Goodnough
title: States Vow Extra Scrutiny of Coronavirus Vaccine
description: Special committees, mostly in Democratic-led states, will seek to reassure the public that an F.D.A.-approved vaccine is safe and effective amid doubts about the Trump administration’s virus response.
content: Within weeks, the Food and Drug Administration is expected to review safety and efficacy data for what may be the first Covid-19 vaccine in the United States, with hopes of immunizing some Americans soon after.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Biden and Harris will speak about the economy today.
description: As the nation faces the twin crises of the coronavirus pandemic and an economy it has ravaged, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris will speak this afternoon about their long-term plans to oversee the recovery.
content: As the nation faces the twin crises of the coronavirus pandemic and an economy it has ravaged, President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris will speak this afternoon about their long-term plans to oversee the recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: Early Data Show Moderna’s Coronavirus Vaccine Is 94.5% Effective
description: Moderna is the second company to report preliminary results from a large trial testing a vaccine. But there are still months to go before it will be widely available to the public.
content: [Read more on Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: How to Do Thanksgiving With Less Waste
description: For environmental advocates, it includes small measures like reusing ingredients, and broader efforts like rethinking our relationship to the holiday.
content: DeVonne Jackson’s earliest memories of Thanksgiving begin with her grandmother Velma Jackson, who prepared curried goat while singing the folksy Jamaican tune “Ram Goat Liver.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Instead of Regaining Momentum, Johnson Is Stalled at Home Again
description: The British prime minister begins 14 days of self-isolation after meeting with a lawmaker who tested positive for the coronavirus just as he tries to shake off bitter fighting within his administration.
content: LONDON — For Prime Minister Boris Johnson, this was supposed to be a critical week to reset his government after a tumultuous round of infighting that led to the abrupt ouster of his most influential adviser, Dominic Cummings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Global Financial Stability Watchdog Warns That Markets Remain Vulnerable
description: The Treasury market seized up in March, and the Financial Stability Board said in a new report that it could happen again.
content: WASHINGTON — A financial market meltdown in March highlighted weaknesses that still pose a threat to global financial stability, indicating the need for reform, a global body that monitors financial risks said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: Airbnb Reveals Falling Revenue, With Travel Hit by Pandemic
description: The drop was $1.2 billion for the first nine months of 2020, in the first comprehensive look at the company’s finances as it moves to go public.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb, the home rental service that disrupted the travel industry and was itself disrupted by the coronavirus, took a major step toward one of the year’s largest initial public offerings when it revealed declining revenue and growing losses in a prospectus on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay and Ken Belson
title: Florida Lawyer Charged With Extorting N.F.L. Player in Robbery Case
description: William Dean was charged with trying to extort nearly $800,000 from former New York Giant DeAndre Baker in exchange for his clients’ recanting allegations. On Monday, charges against Mr. Baker were dropped.
content: The lawyer representing three men who accused two N.F.L. players of robbery and assault in Florida was arrested on Monday morning and charged with attempting to extort roughly $800,000 from one of the athletes in exchange for having his clients alter their testimony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenn Pelly
title: An Artist Who Paints in Cryptic Pastel Symbols
description: Caroline Kent’s canvases explore the power and limits of language — and challenge the modernist canon of abstraction.
content: Even as a child, Caroline Kent was immersed in the language of abstraction. The Chicago-based artist — whose large-scale black canvases evoke cosmic unknowns — grew up alongside her identical twin sister, Christine Leventhal, with whom she shared special methods of communication. Their conversations can still be so elliptical and condensed that they perplex others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Pannell and Daniel Milroy Maher
title: Have a Look at the Fabled Honey Forest
description: In northeastern Turkey, the beekeeping traditions of the Hemshin people, an ethnic minority originating from Armenia, are both evolving and at risk of vanishing.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Sarah Pannell shares a collection of images from the Turkish province of Rize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: America’s Internet Has China Envy
description: But is China a peek at the future of technology, or a digital island all its own?
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Adno
title: Endless Subscribers: Pro Surfers Follow a New Path to Stardom
description: In the digital era, a carefully crafted persona has become more valuable than contest results.
content: Sterling Spencer, a surfer from Florida, met a heavy dose of skepticism when he left the sport’s professional circuit 12 years ago and built a career through short films rather than competitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Desk Lamps
description: If your work-from-home setup needs an upgrade, a new task light is a good place to start.
content: Since the pandemic struck, improvised home offices have been put through their paces. If your work-from-home setup is ready for an upgrade, the right desk lamp is a good place to start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
title: Biden Calls for Stimulus Ahead of a ‘Dark Winter’ for the Country
description: The president-elect looked to forge unity between business and unions in a speech on the economy.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. warned on Monday of a “very dark winter” ahead and called on Congress to pass a large economic stimulus package immediately to help workers, businesses, and state and local governments struggling to cope with the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Michelle Obama, who helped Melania Trump in 2016, criticizes the Trumps for hindering Biden’s transition.
description: Michelle Obama suggested President Trump was treating the transition like “a game” on Monday and pleaded with Republicans to “honor the electoral process” by accepting Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the president-elect.
content: Michelle Obama suggested President Trump was treating the transition like “a game” on Monday and pleaded with Republicans to “honor the electoral process” by accepting Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the president-elect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Dr. Céline Gounder, Adviser to Biden, on the Next Covid Attack Plan
description: Schools are essential while restaurants are not, said Dr. Gounder. And manufacturers may soon be ordered to produce protective gear for health workers.
content: When President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. takes office in January, he will inherit a pandemic that has convulsed the country. His transition team last week announced a 13-member team of scientists and doctors who will advise on control of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Phoenix Suns Agree to Trade for Chris Paul
description: The trade sends Ricky Rubio and Kelly Oubre Jr. to Oklahoma City for Paul, the veteran point guard.
content: The long-awaited reopening of the N.B.A.’s trade market on Monday delivered an immediate blockbuster that will send Oklahoma City Thunder guard Chris Paul to the Phoenix Suns to join Devin Booker in what has the look of a dynamic backcourt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: For a preview of President Biden, look to his past.
description: Like President Bill Clinton, Joseph R. Biden Jr. is an empathetic extrovert with a sprawling network of friends. Like President George W. Bush, he respects American political traditions, and with President Barack Obama, he shares eight years of history, experiences and some Washington battle scars.
content: Like President Bill Clinton, Joseph R. Biden Jr. is an empathetic extrovert with a sprawling network of friends. Like President George W. Bush, he respects American political traditions, and with President Barack Obama, he shares eight years of history, experiences and some Washington battle scars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Opam
title: Postal Service Takes ‘Operation Santa’ Letter Campaign National
description: The program encourages postal customers to adopt letters and buy gifts for the children who send them. This year, because of the pandemic, customers will review the letters exclusively online.
content: For more than a century, it was a simple way of making a child’s dreams come true during Christmas. Volunteers could go to the post office, sift through piles of letters that children had sent to Santa Claus and pick one — or more — that tugged at their heartstrings. Gifts were then acquired, wrapped and shipped to families whose space beneath the tree might otherwise be bare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Berkman
title: While Training Continues, China’s Prized Women’s Hockey Players Are in Russia
description: With the 2022 Winter Games 15 months away, at a time teams would normally be paring their rosters, the North American imports aren’t in the Beijing training bubble.
content: The players most crucial to Chinese women’s ice hockey reside in a hotel about 70 miles south of Moscow. The quasi resort’s expansive grounds contain horses, stray cats and a speleochamber — a salt cave designed to improve breathing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump has amplified voting falsehoods in over 300 tweets since election night.
description: The president has mischaracterized the ballot counting process, falsely claimed victory and lodged baseless accusations of fraud.
content: President Trump has posted over 300 tweets attacking the integrity of the 2020 election since election night, unleashing a cascade of false and misleading claims. Here’s a review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Yu and Hisako Ueno
title: Japanese ‘Monster Wolf’ Aims to Scare Off Wild Bears
description: After bears kept venturing into the city in search of food, officials installed mechanical wolves with bared teeth, glowing red eyes and a fearsome screech to keep the animals away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Was It Worth It, Jared and Ivanka?
description: The glossiest grifters become Vuitton vagabonds.
content: Just five short years ago Jared and Ivanka were dinner-party royalty here in Manhattan. It’s that kind of place. They had money, they had youth, they had celebrity. They were thin. I’m told that their manners were impeccable, so you’d never know that his father was an actual felon and her father a de facto one. Besides, you can’t hold family against someone, can you? We don’t choose how we’re born.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spain’s Other Covid Casualties: Undetected Cancer Cases
description: A raft of lawsuits has emerged from a health care system where the struggle to fight the pandemic has led to neglect of other serious conditions.
content: MADRID — Last March, as the coronavirus was tearing across Spain, Lídia Bayona Gómez started to suffer bouts of vomiting and coughing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Recipes to Alter Your Mood
description: Get out of your head, and make something new, whether its barbecue chicken pizza, mozzarella in carrozza or a lentil-sweet potato salad.
content: Good morning. “Tomorrow was another day, at least by the calendar,” the novelist Patrick O’Brian wrote in “Blue at the Mizzen,” “but the two could hardly be told apart: the heat, the faintly drifting cloud, the ship pitching heavily with no way on her, the flaccid sails, were all the same.” It’s been like that for a lot of us lately, stuck on our ships in the doldrums of lockdown, marking the passage of time with meals that take on an unrelenting sameness: a breakfast, a lunch, a dinner, repeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Bruno Barbey, Magnum Photographer of War and Peace, Dies at 79
description: He was “a formidable visual architect” who captured the streets of Paris during the violent demonstrations in 1968 and documented the human experience in other parts of the world.
content: Bruno Barbey, a French photographer for the Magnum Photos agency who produced powerful, empathetic work in war zones as well as in peacetime, died on Nov. 9 in Orbais-l’Abbaye, in northeastern France. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Trump Administration, in Late Push, Moves to Sell Oil Rights in Arctic Refuge
description: The lease sales could occur just before Inauguration Day, leaving the administration of Joseph R. Biden Jr. to try to reverse them after the fact.
content: The Trump administration on Monday announced that it would begin the formal process of selling leases to oil companies in a last-minute push to achieve its long-sought goal of allowing oil and gas drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Left to fend for themselves as the coronavirus spread and New Yorkers lost their jobs en masse, undocumented immigrants turned to one of the few options left: selling food on the street.
